üéØ Add Two Numbers - Brute Force Visualization

Interactive Step-by-Step Walkthrough with Animations

üìã Problem Setup

Given: Two linked lists representing numbers in REVERSE order

List 1 (l1):
2
‚Üí
4
‚Üí
3
‚Üí
null

Represents: 342

List 2 (l2):
5
‚Üí
6
‚Üí
4
‚Üí
null

Represents: 465

Expected Output: [7, 0, 8] ‚Üí Represents 807
üí° Brute-Force Strategy
Step 1
Convert l1 ‚Üí 342
‚ûú
Step 2
Convert l2 ‚Üí 465
‚ûú
Step 3
Add: 342 + 465
‚ûú
Step 4
Convert 807 ‚Üí [7,0,8]
üî¢ STEP 1: Convert l1 to Number
1

Goal: Build the number 342 from [2,4,3]

üîÑ Iteration 1: Process node(2)
Position: Ones place
current.val = 2
num1 = 0 + (2 √ó 1) = 2
multiplier = 1 √ó 10 = 10

State: num1 = 2, multiplier = 10

üîÑ Iteration 2: Process node(4)
Position: Tens place
current.val = 4
num1 = 2 + (4 √ó 10) = 42
multiplier = 10 √ó 10 = 100

State: num1 = 42, multiplier = 100

üîÑ Iteration 3: Process node(3)
Position: Hundreds place
current.val = 3
num1 = 42 + (3 √ó 100) = 342
current = null ‚Üí DONE!

State: num1 = 342 ‚úì

‚úÖ RESULT: l1 = [2,4,3] ‚Üí num1 = 342
üî¢ STEP 2: Convert l2 to Number
2

Goal: Build the number 465 from [5,6,4]

üîÑ Iteration 1: Process node(5)
Position: Ones place
current.val = 5
num2 = 0 + (5 √ó 1) = 5
multiplier = 1 √ó 10 = 10

State: num2 = 5, multiplier = 10

üîÑ Iteration 2: Process node(6)
Position: Tens place
current.val = 6
num2 = 5 + (6 √ó 10) = 65
multiplier = 10 √ó 10 = 100

State: num2 = 65, multiplier = 100

üîÑ Iteration 3: Process node(4)
Position: Hundreds place
current.val = 4
num2 = 65 + (4 √ó 100) = 465
current = null ‚Üí DONE!

State: num2 = 465 ‚úì

‚úÖ RESULT: l2 = [5,6,4] ‚Üí num2 = 465
‚ûï STEP 3: Add the Numbers
3
num1 = 342
+ num2 = 465
‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
sum = 807
‚úÖ Addition Complete: sum = 807
üîÑ STEP 4: Convert Sum Back to Linked List
4

Goal: Convert 807 ‚Üí [7,0,8] (reverse order)

üîÑ Iteration 1: Extract ones digit
digit = sum % 10 = 807 % 10 = 7
Create node(7)
sum = sum / 10 = 807 / 10 = 80

Result: [7] ‚Üí null

üîÑ Iteration 2: Extract tens digit
digit = sum % 10 = 80 % 10 = 0
Create node(0)
sum = sum / 10 = 80 / 10 = 8

Result: [7] ‚Üí [0] ‚Üí null

üîÑ Iteration 3: Extract hundreds digit
digit = sum % 10 = 8 % 10 = 8
Create node(8)
sum = sum / 10 = 8 / 10 = 0 ‚Üí DONE!

Result: [7] ‚Üí [0] ‚Üí [8] ‚Üí null

‚úÖ FINAL OUTPUT: [7, 0, 8] representing 807
üéØ Complete Visualization

INPUT

l1: [2] ‚Üí [4] ‚Üí [3]
l2: [5] ‚Üí [6] ‚Üí [4]
‚¨áÔ∏è
num1 = 342
num2 = 465
‚¨áÔ∏è
sum = 807
‚¨áÔ∏è

OUTPUT

[7] ‚Üí [0] ‚Üí [8]
Verification:
342 + 465 = 807 ‚úÖ

‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL PROBLEM: Why This Approach FAILS!

Constraint: Lists can have up to 100 nodes

Maximum number: 10100 - 1 (a 100-digit number!)

JavaScript Number Type Limitation:
‚Ä¢ Uses 64-bit floating point (IEEE 754)
‚Ä¢ Max safe integer: 253 - 1 ‚âà 9 √ó 1015
‚Ä¢ Only handles ~16 digits accurately!
Example that BREAKS:
l1 = [9,9,9,9,...,9] (100 nines)
l2 = [1]

‚ùå num1 would be 10100 - 1
‚ùå JavaScript can't store this!
‚ùå Precision loss ‚Üí INCORRECT RESULT
JavaScript can handle: ~16 digits
Problem requires: up to 100 digits

16 ‚â™ 100 ‚Üê HUGE GAP!
üìä Complexity Analysis
‚è±Ô∏è

Time Complexity

O(max(n, m))

‚Ä¢ Convert l1: O(n)
‚Ä¢ Convert l2: O(m)
‚Ä¢ Add: O(1)
‚Ä¢ Convert back: O(max(n,m))

üíæ

Space Complexity

O(max(n, m))

‚Ä¢ Result list: max(n,m) + 1 nodes
‚Ä¢ Temp variables: O(1)
‚Ä¢ Total: O(max(n,m))

Note: Good complexity but ‚ùå WRONG ANSWER for large inputs!
üìù Summary Table
Step Input Process Output
1 l1=[2,4,3] Multiply & sum: 2√ó1 + 4√ó10 + 3√ó100 num1=342
2 l2=[5,6,4] Multiply & sum: 5√ó1 + 6√ó10 + 4√ó100 num2=465
3 num1=342, num2=465 Standard addition sum=807
4 sum=807 Extract digits: 807‚Üí7, 80‚Üí0, 8‚Üí8 [7,0,8]
‚úÖ Result matches expected output!
‚ùå Only works for numbers ‚â§ 16 digits
üéì Key Takeaways

‚úÖ What Works:

Brute-force works perfectly for SMALL numbers (< 16 digits)

‚ùå What Fails:

Brute-force FAILS for LARGE numbers (‚â• 16 digits)

üîç Why It Fails:

  • Integer overflow
  • Precision loss in floating point
  • Violates problem constraints

üí° What We Learned:

  • % operator extracts rightmost digit
  • / 10 shifts number right (removes last digit)
  • Multiplier pattern builds place values

üöÄ Next Step:

‚Üí Need digit-by-digit addition (no conversion!)
‚Üí Avoids integer overflow
‚Üí Handles arbitrary precision
